content.body: http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/ietf-http-wg/2009JulSep/0397.html (Yngve on tab-level cookies)
not to interrupt anybody's stellar evening, just wanting to stir up conversation with regards to an email I sent to the list: http://lists.whatwg.org/htdig.cgi/whatwg-whatwg.org/2009-July/021578.html
will the html5 specification include requirements about the content generated for the 'contenteditable' attribute? i'd love to see an acid test for that one...
bchoate: what kind of requirements?
MikeSmith: that browsers produce valid html5 markup for instance
bchoate:
bchoate: ah
and preferably not include garbage like class="Apple-style-span" or class="Mso-Normal", etc.
interesting case.. I don't think it's currently a requirement that they produce valid html
one man's garbage is another man's feature

nathanhammond: seems like some of those are questions that Hixie needs to answer himself. And he seems particularly snowed under lately, so I'd guess you might have to wait for a bit before you get a reply from him.
MikeSmith: I was getting that impression
nathanhammond: I'd suspect it's possible that Hixie may not have even made time yet to read that message.
nods
I was guessing that may be the case.
nathanhammond: but regardless, I'd recommend continuing to ask here
the squeaky wheel gets the grease, and all that
indeed, and I was curious if anybody else had comments
but as is probably the case most of the time people are very interested in one subsection of the spec
(just like me)
yeah
sometimes it seems to me like the blind men and the elephant
nathanhammond: especially in context of some of the "HTML5 is a mess" comments
and you just hope that all of the blind men get a chance to explain what their experience is
what most people mean when they say that kind of stuff is, "This one particular part of the spec, which is the main/only part that I care about personally, is a mess."
nathanhammond: yeah
nathanhammond: so are you the owner for the history feature in Chrome? the UI and all?
MikeSmith: I am not, I mostly stick to client-side code
OK
I wrote JSSM and am working on a HTML 5 History shim
nathanhammond: I've never tried JSSM, but will take a look
don't!
my main history-management mechanism is to keep a bunch of tabs open
I would really like to have something better and easier/natural to use
hah, this is for websites
ah
my beef with most History features is that they just get in my way
I agree, I do the tab thing
with session saving on close
(in the event that Flash pegs the cpu)
reads more about JSSM and also http://nathanhammond.com/google-chrome-and-history-management
out of date now
*grin*
but I still haven't been able to track down that issue.
no resolution on the bug?
the last time I tried to track it down I still could not successfully isolate it
I hear rumor that the issue has disappeared in current versions of Chrome
but without the unit tests that I've been writing for the updated version it really hasn't been a mature project
nathanhammond: i'm about 10 days behind on the list
bchoate: the spec says that the UA must generate valid content
Hixie: oh that's good to hear -- where does it say that? i'm looking at http://www.w3.org/TR/html5/editing.html but maybe that isn't the latest draft?
Hixie: I'll be patient. *grin*

bchoate: for example, under "break block": "The exact behavior is UA-dependent, but user agents must not, in response to a request to break a paragraph, generate a DOM that is less conformant than the DOM prior to the request."
Hixie: ok i see - thanks
Hixie: why is xmp equivalent to code rather than pre?
zcorpan: is that wrong?
zcorpan: i thought it was an inline element, no?
i didn't look too closely
so i may well have gotten it wrong
hmm, how many windows-1252 documents are mislabelled as iso-* encodings?  I'm betting it's more than .2%
who made that claim?

annevk2, Larry did when he made a sarcastic comment saying "The advice for the few "public browser" implementors who feel compelled to also deal with the increasing their compatibility with existing web sites from 67% to 67.2% of existing content by supporting odd, broken character transformations."
sighs
Philip` can probably get you a list of iso-8859-1 pages that use the win1252 characters easily enough
maybe all Adobe employees have mandatory "how to act like a troll" training
notices it's less than 8 hours until his meeting, and decides to not go to his meeting
I'm not really interested in proving him wrong
Done that a lot before and he just continues to apply his rethoric to something completely different ignoring what you said
apparently i'm working on a fork of html5
larry masinter never did reply to my e-mail asking him what he meant by that

I don't trivially have that data (e.g. http://philip.html5.org/data/charsets.html says 100% of iso-8859-1 pages were considered valid by the decoder, probably because it doesn't forbid win-1252 characters)
speaking of people who don't reply to e-mail...
and would probably have to write more Java code to extract that data
and I don't care enough
Philip`: i just meant search for [\x80-\x9f]
Hixie: I'd have to write code to search for that
grep won't do it?
grep won't restrict it to iso-8859-1-declared pages
wonders what "his meeting" is
i'd search for it myself, but unfortunately my corpus is post-conversion-to-utf-8
takkaria: I was going to comment on that, but I lost heart before I finished my email reply
MikeSmith: are we going to have a survey on who is attending the meeting in november?
What should typeof HTMLElement give?
the alternative helding it at Google proposal is not going through btw?

Hixie, I assume Larry simply used the term fork incorrectly to refer to your's and Manu's specs as competing alternatives, rather than Manu's as simply being a supplimentary section to be considered for inclusion.
isn't Manu's spec in fact a full-text alternative?
othermaciej: There are both forms
should be easy to recast as a standalone spec, then, if the author were so inclined
othermaciej, AIUI, when he generates it, he takes the trunk at the time and inserts his new section into it, and then publishes both as a standalone and incorporated version
I do note though that he didn't remove the microdata section, at least not yet
Hixie: yeah, I set up the survey already
MikeSmith, what survey?
I'll get the URL
oh, I guess Hixie meant the TPAC survey
Lachy: yeah
which makes me wonder even more why Sam felt compelled to mix microdata into my suggestion about RDFa
I hope it's not too late to register for TPAC, as I have been too lazy to do so
Hixie: xmp a block element
zcorpan: huh go figure
zcorpan: i'll fix it, thanks
othermaciej, I don't believe it is
Otherwise, no-one at Opera will be attended, as we're all waiting on Chaals to make up his mind about who to send
zcorpan: done
when does the price go up?
it's $250 each right now right?
for the week?
really? That's a lot.  Didn't it used to be $50?  Did it go up once already, or have I just remembered incorrectly?
Lachy: $50 per day
ah, ok.
Did someone here not link to something by Steven Pemberton yesterday?
s/yesterday/two days ago/
http://www.pemberton.nl/vandf/2009/07/xhtml2-not-dead.html
gsnedders: Many people did not link to it
Many did not, but annevk did
"Ian Hickson sings the praise of those modules elsewhere."
Why the return type of HTMLInputElement::list() is HTMLElement instead of HTMLDataListElement?
othermaciej: it's not too late. I'll try to get the green light on announcing the registration survey by beginning of next week
othermaciej: please cajole hyatt into going, if you can
MikeSmith: it's less convenient for hyatt than for me, but I'll ask if he's interested
and would be great to meet other webkit folks f2f
Apple people based in Cupertino would be more likely to be available
yeah, understood
zcorpan, I thought that was funny too; the post he points to is 7y old or so :)
Was Dean Jackson not the only Apple guy last year?
Dave Singer was there too
I seem to remember at least
I don't remember meeting him…
if othermaciej can get hyatt to go, i'll be impressed
tkent_: ping Hixie about that
hyatt hates standards meetings
on the whole doubts he'll be going
Hixie, how about that?

wonders if it's worth pointing out that the 'decentralised' identifier problem can't be solved with DNS, because DNS relies on centralised authorities, and all you're doing is pushing the centralisation away by a few levels of abstraction
gsnedders, "object"
(for typeof HTMLElement)
heycam: k, thx
tkent: i think at some point <select> was allowed as a target also
I am mainly interested in going for the chance to meet people in person that I might not have met at all, or don't get to talk to regularly
not really expecting valuable technical breakthroughs
Philip`: in practice, dns is decentralised enough
Hixie: ok, I understand.  Thanks.
gsnedders, while you're reporting things like HTMLUnknownElement maybe you should investigate XMLDocument and such too
annevk2: I'm really working on other stuff now though
gsnedders, never mind then
hey i don't suppose any of you feel like writing the scripts that would autogenerate the index tables would you?
i recently figured out what the columns should be
it looked pretty complex
we've never had HTMLUnknownElement
I wonder if Yahoo Mail Beta fails for us, or does something different
A generic index of all dfns I have a plan for
othermaciej: You get WebKit specific JS
(Likewise IE gets its own too)
does Opera get the same as Firefox?
HTMLUnknownElement seems like a really goofy idea, but I guess it's far from the dumbest thing in the web platform

Hixie: The "enough" is just a consequence of various factors (like the ease of registering non-conflicting names, and robustness to failures, etc), rather than there being a fundamental binary difference to e.g. a centralised wiki page, so there might be lots of other options that are somewhere in the middle
othermaciej: I haven't checked exactly, but from the brief look I took it seems so
othermaciej: if you send an e-mail saying we shouldn't have it, that's pretty much all it would take to convince me to go back to using HTMLElement
Philip`: preaching to the choir :-)
so I think it's a bit misleading to think of decentralised vs centralised, because it's all just different degrees of where the centralisation occurs

(it seems bogus because it can stop working if an element stops being "unknown", and also because many actual recognizedelements are just vanilla HTMLElement, so it seems weird to cater more to unrecognized ones)
gsnedders, why did we not want the WebKit codepath?
no argument from me there
As long as websites break if we remove it (esp. high profile ones like Y! Mail beta), it's unlikely we'll remove it
Hixie: Good, that must mean I'm not totally crazy (at least relative to this environment) :-)
othermaciej: send mail :-)
annevk2: I tried UA sniffing, and it never finished loading
*spoofing
http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-dom/2009JulSep/0125.html touche othermaciej!
I'll consider it tomorrow and maybe send mail
gsnedders: Make the browser detect if the user works for Yahoo, and if so then do the sane thing that breaks Yahoo Mail, so they notice and fix the problem, without it affecting many real users
:P
what's a good thing to use as an example for how to use microdata
annevk2: yeah I wasn't sure if I should send that, but I have forgiven myself this minor sin
Hixie: http://quotes.burntelectrons.org/4288
Hixie: semantic markup for photos of a model train collection?
Hixie, markup for your StarGate DVD collection?
or has that example been overused?
let me rephrase my question
It seems better to have examples that would be slightly more relevant for normal people
what's a good thing to use as an example for how to use microdata *that someone would actually care about and do something with*
ignores othermaciej for his rudeness in that email
rather than your typical semantic web examples of "mark everything up and maybe it'll be useful one day"
Hixie: Do we actually have examples like that in HTML 5? :\
are there any such examples?
gsnedders: it wasn't chronic!
How dull.
(can't say as to insufferable)
Hixie: Something from the list of use cases that motivated the inclusion of microdata in the spec
Hixie, markup for a TV guide?
ahah ..?
Hixie: what kind of "do something with" - are you interested in examples with prior agreement between producer and consumer, or does it have to be data that unknown unrelated consumers may want?
one example for the prior case would be bugzilla
nm that suggestion
the main use cases were all vcard and vevent related, but i want something where you make up your own vocab, for this example
bugzilla HTML markup changes between different versions, so a script can't reliably screen-scrape
othermaciej: i guess either is fine
ooh, bugzilla's a good one
the XML version is more reliable but completely separate
microdata would let you parse the HTML and reliably extract data in the face of markup changes
Microdata would make the extracted data extremely fragile because it would keep breaking whenever someone changed the markup and forgot to check the microdata was identical in all cases
othermaciej: But why not use the XML interface?
though in general consumers will intend to work with bugzilla specifically and don't need a generic central "bug database" vocabulary
or you could negotiate content and use a more appropriate format than HTML for data interchange? :D
gsnedders: less risk of inconsistency if there's only one interface
othermaciej: Indeed. But there are already two interfaces.
mookid: if using a separate non-HTML formatted value is an appropriate solution, then clearly microdata (or RDFa) won't help
gsnedders: well, two responses on that
(1) but would you design it like that from scratch? we shouldn't assume bugzilla is the only bugzilla-like piece of software ever to be made
do you have to have a head node in an html document for it to be valid?
mookid: Yes, and title within it.
is there a reason for that?
(2) we're intending to customize bugzilla a fair bit for WebKit, and reliable semantic markup in the HTML would be easier to keep in sync with changes than a whole separate XML version
mookid: (The head *tags* are optional, though the element is required)
what's the logic behind that descision?
page titles are an essential part of a page
othermaciej: (1) No; (2) But it seems likely that things already rely upon Bugzilla's XML interface ;(
how are they essential? :/
Hixie: search results would be another good example, if search engines wanted to enable screen scraping instead of being kind of hostile to it
<head><title></title></head> - valid?
you forgot a doctype
othermaciej: the bug example is fine
mookid: No, you need a DOCTYPE and a body element
mookid: <!DOCTYPE html><title</title> I believe is the shortest valid bit of HTML
yeah yeah I just mean the head element
any example I can think of is vulnerable to the criticism that you could just provide a completely separate data interface
othermaciej: yeah, well, there's a reason i'm not a fan of this whole technology concept
why do you require the title though - I don't understand why you would insist on that
however, in the case of bugzilla, having the machine-readable data combined with the human-readable presentation seems intuitively appealing
to me anyway
mookid: whatwg⊙wo or public-html-comments⊙wo
takkaria: I think you might want more >s in there
I don't want to change anything I just want to understand the rationale
fair enough, I don't really have any :)
Philip`: yeah, a couple more won't hurt
I imagine the rationale would be that many systems present HTML documents by title, thus lacking one would be considered an error
doesn't enforcing a title/head element kind of damage HTML as a decent 'fragment' format?
(examples of places where the title shows up: browser titlebar, browser history, browser bookmarks, search engine search results)
if you just want a fragment you do not need a full document (or title)
an HTML fragment doesn't need to be a conforming HTML document
(Browser tabs too)
although I'm not sure there is a conformance class for it
if(!title) title = 'Zomg the end of the world!1!1';
you're welcome.
presumably the fragment context would have to define what kinds of fragments are allowed, and the processing model
annevk2: that's not true if I want my fragments to be crawlable and valid html
think that's a fair requirement, no?
I need some more context for your use case
website that uses html fragments/Ajax also wants individual fragments to be crawlable and valid markup
for SEO etc.
what happened to onbeforeunload?
is auditing the list of event-handler attributes that v.nu knows about against the list in the spec
btw Lachy the blog is still suffering from the effects of a hacker
MikeSmith: it's in, isn't it?
Hixie: it's not in the list in the Global Attributes section
I don't think
doublechecks
it's not a global attribute
ah
it's only on <body> (and <frameset>, though since that element is obsolete, that doesn't matter much)
OK
yeah
hits himself with clue stick
um, if i try to preview a blog post on blog.whatwg.org i get asked for a Magic password?
Hixie, I don't get asked for a password
mookid, titles are important for SEO
Lachy: "To view this page, you must log in to area âMagicâ on blog.whatwg.org:80."
that's for http://blog.whatwg.org/?p=924&preview=true
it worked when i reloaded
wtf
works for me
interesting, WordPress does not lowercase href attributes
darn, I got goaded into writing an anti-namespace jeremiad
Is there anything else to appears to be a result of a hacker?
I almost started flaming back at Larry, but I'll instead pull a Larry and not reply
Lachy: do you see the spam on the front page?
trying to correct all his misconceptions about how the Web works is not worth it
annevk2: or you could pull a Larry by sarcastically misrepresenting his point, and then accusing him of using a strawman argument
Lachy: oh, looks like you fixed it
you guys are killing me
no
schedules 2pm-3pm tomorrow for responding to e-mails from people reading the chat log and complaining to me for not telling you off for being rude about people who are being rude
Hixie: usually takes the log trawlers more than 24 hours to embark on their fishing expeditions
Hixie, were you looking at a cached copy of the page?
Lachy: yeah, maybe
ok
clearly i don't know how to use web browsers
whoah, MLW is now trolling in near real-time
soon i'll be ready to work for w3c
i am happy to say that i haven't looked at MLW in at least 6 months now, possibly more
othermaciej, yeah, I have a strong suspicion that MLW is someone who is in this channel
I just haven't figured out who
I hadn't looked in a while until you mentioned having to deal with people reading the chat log
I was subscribed to that blog for a while, but it got really boring
the sarcastic posts can be amusing but lately it seems he's descended to just stringing together swear words
MLW has also claimed to affiliated with the W3C in some way http://twitter.com/MrLastWeek/status/2530468490
though, admittedly, the message is vague and it isn't clear what "activities of an official W3C nature" may be.
I think we just gave him more attention than he deserves
mea culpa
ok, blogged about microdata on the whatwg blog
link!
make sure it's got a .html on the end of it please
mookid, why?
http://blog.whatwg.org/microdata1
just being an idiot, ignore me

Hixie: I think your examples would be less misleading if they used a real domain, instead of something unnaturally short like example.org, e.g. it's going to be more like <body item="org.mozilla.bugzilla.bug">
Philip`, it could just as easily be org.mozilla.bug
it would actually just be org.bugzilla.bug
which is only one character longer
i considered using ch.hixie.bug, since that's what i would use
(and that's even shorter!)
anyway. bed time. nn.
I saw a 4 character domain the other day, something like a.gh or some such
http://e.dk/
thought the minimum was 4
5, doh
Lachy, so we fixed the spam problem on the blog we found the other day?
Lachy, also, can we upload a new skin that at least enables people to see the name of the person who posted?
annevk2, yeah. Some hacker had somehow modified the templates. That's now been removed and prevented
Lachy, it would be even better if turned on the skin Ben made
which skin did Ben make?
a nice green one
Has it been uploaded to blog.whatwg.org?
I don't think so
or is it available from somewhere?
actually, it was not a skin, it was a design done in HTML/CSS
but it would be easy to make the blog use it I think, maybe email him?
http://a.gd/
well, if someone converts it to a WP template, I can install it easily
MikeSmith, cheerio
what's his email?
➡.ws is only four characters too
not in ASCII
Who cares about ASCII?
HTTP
who cares about HTTP?
Who cares that HTTP cares about ASCII?
doesn't HTTP use ISO-8859-1?
(I don't care that it's a superset of ASCII)
(I don't care about your question)
I don't care.
great :)
wow, another lawsuit against TPB http://torrentfreak.com/italian-riaa-suesthe-pirate-bay-for-1-million-euros-090731/
I guess the MAFIAA are just going to keep suing them in every country they can
what better things have they go to do with themselves, really?
takkaria, they could spend their time and money on developing better and more sustainable business models
Suing people for a million dollars seems like a good business model
what, rather than operating under the assumption that one day the Internet will be un-invented?
not when they know the defendants won't pay
emailed Ben
takkaria, very few things have been uninvented
I guess lots of things invented in ancient Egypt and ancient Greece etc have been uninvented
if you consider uninvented to mean technology that we have lost all knowledge of through history
Yes - inventing is the gaining of knowledge of how to do something, and uninventing is the losing of that knowledge
Lachy: I think my preferred approach for them would be just to keep on doing what they're doing except keep the money they're paying lawyers for themselves
that way they'll retire earlier and eventually new people will start managing the music companies who have a clue
wonders why everyone focuses on TPB when there's dozens of other large torrent sites
well, mininova and isohunt have started talking to the movie industry I believe to start self-censoring
doesn't remember it taking long for TPB to gain prominence when Suprnova was shut down

TPB will probably die in a month anyway, and openbittorrent.org and publicbt.org will take over as the word's main trackers, and torrent files will start being distributed through other means, raising the bar for the MAFIAA again
so I suppose I'm assuming someone else will take over in the near future
Lachy: Trackers aren't really interesting - the important thing is a decent-quality searchable index of torrents, which is an orthogonal problem

it wouldn't surprise me if someone set up a torrent site that is run using technoloy like Freenet, so that they don't host the material themselves and anyone is free to anonymously add torrents to the network
How do you ensure quality in that situation?
that would be a challenge
Indeed
but even TPB didn't do much to ensure quality, since they never removed torrents
As far as I'm aware they managed to avoid being overwhelmed by mislabelled torrents and virus-infected programs
(It's particularly a problem when people are being paid to intentionally disrupt the system and reduce its value to users)
I think the most likely end result is most people using a wider spread of trackers
and tools may emerge to make that really much easier
e.g. trackers supporting OpenSearch and a site/app searching a lot of trackers for you
could become built-in to torrent apps themselves
Why would the people running trackers want to cooperate with the people who are running aggregators/search engines and taking all the ad revenue away from the trackers?
non-profit trackers?
/ other private trackers
Philip`, trackers like openbittorrent.org and publicbt.org aren't ad supported. But are you referring to sites that actually host the torrents?
it would be nice to have a service dedicated to hosting the torrents files, and only providing an API for indexing sites
that would make the search sites largely immune from lawsuits since, like Google and other search engines, they don't host or have any control over the torrents themselves
look what I found!
http://whitepapers.theregister.co.uk/paper/view/814/oracle-814.pdf (not a pdf!)
I guess they didn't get the "URI's have special endings because that's what the most cleverest(tm) developers do" memo
maybe they got the memo that stated that URIs are opaque strings
huhuhu :)
couldn't agree more.
wonders if IE copes
(As don't IE still do sniffing based upon extension?)
http://www.theage.com.au/technology/biz-tech/shock-threat-to-shut-skype-20090731-e3qe.html

[13:37] <Philip`> If you encode the desired content-type in the URI, it's not possible for a general-purpose HTTP-processing device to understand what's the resource identifier and what's the content-type selector, because there's no standard for encoding that stuff in URIs
[13:38] <Hixie> Philip`: such a standard or convention could be easily established
annevk2 ^
Opera does some sniffing by file extension...
where is the spec that suggests that is a good idea?
I imagine it's stuffed up someone's arse
if it's not in a spec that sounds like a very BAD idea
it's a bad idea
mostly because sniffing based on the first few  bytes is a far more effective streategy
or Content-Type header? -_-
mookid: Content-Type sniffing in general is a bad idea, but needed for web compat., and until recently there was nowhere near any consensus on how to do it
gsnedders: actually, sniffing is more effective
in hindsight, content-type and content negotation were pretty bad ideas
takkaria: I never questioned that :P
this is the exact reason that HTTP has headers for.
yeah, that was a mental typo.  s/gsnedders/mookid/
It's pure mental, like
notes that joke will probably be lost on everyone outside of the UK
and indeed, me
s/the UK/Scotland/ then maybe
annevk2: you keep saying that about content negotiation
there is nothing to support that assertion whatsoever
other than the *pathetic* support for it in browsers/html which tend to dictate how web mechanisms are leveraged in practice
if you don't have html or browsers in your web architecture there is no problem with conneg at all
there's also very little web. :)
HTTP is the web
URIs
html/browsers are a necessary evil

mookid: Quite frankly, we've been over this several times here already. We've given plenty reasons to support that assertion, though they seemingly have fallen on deaf ears. You aren't going to get a different response by rehashing the same arguments. If you want to get a greater diversity of responses, email whatwg⊙wo/public-html-comments⊙wo
I'm not really sure how to put my argument
annevk2: maybe you don't have one then? :p
mookid: Well, I'm sure if you ask timbl he'll tell you originally HTTP _was_ HTML and URLs, and that everything else was added on later.
I think what I believe is that if an idea does not get a good implementation over a decade it is simply not worth it and should be dropped (and is a bad idea in hindsight)
what tbl thinks is irrelevant realy
the web is HTTP/URIs
Services on HTTP and RIA's are the web
browsers and html are important to the web on a practical level but they don't actually have anything to do with the underlying architecture
Hixie: You still awake?
gsnedders was just talking about the original idea of the Web
so what the original implementation of HTTP was pretty poorly concieved anyway
and the Web and the fundamental architecture of it are separate concepts in my mind
the fundemental driver of success is the architecture
mookid: It's a legacy you won't escape from, though, the poorly concieved original
not if we have standards bodies populated by individuals with the predisposition to continue this insanty, no.
so do something about it
mookid: Well you seem quite uninterested to actually do anything about it, and prefer to just complain on IRC.
talking here won't really further your cause
well, I suppose it might, but given the length of this conversation I'm pretty sure nobody is reading
http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html/2009Jul/0807.html
Where in the select section?
Poor governance basically http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government_failure
also, I have the feeling that each time I chat with you you're saying the same things...
(and I'm repeating myself too)
right - that's mainly because you repeat stuff that doesn't make sense
like
"conneg is broken"
mookid: We've given plenty of reasons, too, but you've ignored them all.
mainly because you're rationale is based entirely on insufficiencies on markup/browser insufficiencies
and nothing to do with the actually Web
actual^

ah-ha! "If the multiple attribute is absent, whenever an option element in the select element's list of options has its selectedness set to true, and whenever an option element with its selectedness set to true is added to the select element's list of options, the user agent must set the selectedness of all the other option element in its list of options to false."
ok, i'll just ignore you now until you have something constructive
mookid: We've given plenty of other reasons too.
you haven't actually mate I wouldn't waste my time if you had
if you point me to the part of the spec where Conneg is flawed, fair enough
otherwise you're just holding someone's head under the water and having a go at them for not being able to swim properly
everyone can write a spec that is technically sound
that does not mean it's good
ok so maybe next time the HTTP guys should do it with phonetically spelled words and nice pictures?
and special gold star stickers if you manage to actually read the damn spec properly
I guess the employees of W3C who wrote HTML 4.0 are equally incompetent in your view?
If the W3C has been so incompetent for the past twelve years, what makes you think it will change?
I think they have way more excuses than you lot do.
mookid: I think your continual repetition of the same positions is not constructive and borders on trolling
terrific
ironically unconstructive comment

annevk: I think legend would be an excellent element to use with figure and details, except every major browser has issues with it, and not because they did anything wrong. HTML 4 defines legend, as a form element, to be a replaced element. Undoing that is a radical change in definition.
I don't think HTML4 defined it as such

cgriego: I agree. I tried to some DOM Scripting with <details> and it proved to be impossible because of the way that browsers interpret the presence of the <legend> element (Safari throws it away, Firefox generates a <fieldset>).
The problem is ...what's the alternative?
(in theory it should be treated as an unknown element outside of <fieldset>)
to elaborate a little bit, one of the other goals we have is keeping the language simple
and as browsers fix their bugs <legend> will become useful
it might take a little longer, but not having to introduce a new element seems worth it
annevk: I agree and I think that Safari and Firefox will probably fix this pretty quickly but IE (again) is going to really slow things down.
I've read through the arguments for and against <legend>: http://lists.whatwg.org/htdig.cgi/whatwg-whatwg.org/2008-February/014038.html
And I agree, in principle, that it's far more preferable to "recycle" an existing element than to create a new one.
But I'd really like to be able to use the new HTML5 elements and as long as some of them use <legend>, they're effectively out of bounds. :-(
Remy has a more detailed breakdown of the issues: http://html5doctor.com/legend-not-such-a-legend-anymore/
yeah, it's dilemma
